introduction.p:
Even a small amount of charge corresponds to a large number of electrons. For instance, a nano Coulomb of charge, which is not much as far as charges go, would contain about 10^{10} electrons. Therefore, rather than treat such large collection of charges individually, we model them as distributed continuously with a charge density, i.e., charge per unit volume, which we will denote by the Greek symbol \rho, pronunced as rho.
\rho = \dfrac{q}{V}.
This is similar to mass density you are familiar with, but with one diffrence - charge density can be positive and negative, depending on the type of charge q. Thus, if you remove some electrons from a neutral body, the charge density of the body will be positive, and if you place extra electron on a neutral body, the body will have negative charge density.

Often charge density will vary in the same body. For instance, if we place some extra charge on a metal cone, then charge density at the tip will tend to be larger than elsewhere. That means, we should think of \rho as a function of location, i.e., \rho (x, y, z).

Often we work with charges distributed only on the surface. For instance, when we place some charge on a metal, the charges tend to spread out at the surface only. That means, we will have charge per unit area rather than charge per unit volume. This is called surface charge density, which is denoted by Greek letter \sigma, sigma.
\sigma = \dfrac{q}{A}.

We also work with charges on wires and such, where we can think of charge per unit length. This type of charge density is called line charge density. It is denoted by the Greek letter \lambda, lambda.
\lambda = \dfrac{q}{L}.

subsection.title: Electric Field of Continuous Charges
subsection.p: Here I will list electric field formulas for some illustrative continuous charge distributions. To work out these results requires Calculus and is relegated to worked out examples below.

subsubsection.title: Electric Field of a Charged Rod
subsubsection.p: First case of interest is the electric field of a uniformly charged thin rod of length L with line charge density \lambda (SI units: \text{C/m}). We right away note that the direction of electric firld is away from the rod if \lambda is positive and towards the rod if \lambda is negative.

sidebyside.p:
In , I show that electric field at a point P that is at a distance D from the middle of the rod has magnitude
E = k\dfrac{ 2|q| }{ D \sqrt{ L^2 + 4D^2} },
where |q|=|\lambda| L, the total charge on the rod.

subsubsection.p:
Note that this formula does not look anything like the electric field of a point charge. In particular, if you get very close to the rod such that we have L\gt\gt D, the field drops of as 1/D rather than 1/D^2.
E = k\dfrac{ 2|\lambda| }{ D}\ \ \text{if}\ \ L\gt\gt D.
However, if we looked at a point P that is far away, we expect the rod to be more like point charge and field drops with distance as 1/D^2, as we get when we apply D\gt\gt L to Eq. .
E_x \amp = k\, \dfrac{q}{D^2}\text{, if } D\gt\gt L.

example.title: (Calculus) Electric Field of a Uniformly Charged Thin Rod

sidebyside.p:
Suppose we have a uniformly charged rod of length L with line charge density \lambda and we want to find field at P in . The electric field is given in Eq. .
E = k\dfrac{ 2|q| }{ D \sqrt{ L^2 + 4D^2} },

example.p: Now, we will like to derive this result from the fundametal formula for electric field of a point charge.

When we deal with a continuous charges, it is helpful to start with pieces of the body, and use point charge formula. Whenever possible, it usually simplifies calculation if you make use of the symmetry. In the present question, since the field point is in the plane that divides the rod in half, there is a symmetry between the upper half and lower half.

To exploit symmetry in the situation, we will look at electric fields from two small parts of the rod that are symmetrucally placed shown as dq_1 and dq_2 in . Note that the symmetry leads to the cancellation of y component. Hence, we just need to work out E_x. furthermore, we can find E_x from one half of the rod and double that.

figure.caption: This figure illustrates that vertical components of the electric fields of two symmetrically placed charge elements will cancel out.

example.p:
From element of the rod between y and y+dy, shown in the upper part of the rod in the x-component of the electric field, to be written informally in infinitesimal notation of dE_x, is
dE_x \amp = k \dfrac{\lambda\, dy}{ D^2 + y^2 }\, \cos\theta \amp = k \dfrac{\lambda\, dy}{ D^2 + y^2 }\, \dfrac{D}{ \sqrt{D^2 + y^2} }
To get the net electric field from the rod we will integrate the right side from y=0 to y=L/2 and multiply the result by 2 to take into account the contributions of the lower half.
E_x \amp = 2\times k\,\lambda\, D \int_0^{L/2} \dfrac{dy}{ \left( D^2 + y^2 \right)^{3/2} }.
I will use Wolfram Alpha to find the integral
\int \dfrac{dy}{ \left( D^2 + y^2 \right)^{3/2} } = \dfrac{y}{D^2\sqrt{y^2 + D^2}} + C.
Therefore, we will get following answer for our problem.
E_x \amp = 2\times k\,\lambda\, \dfrac{L/2}{D\sqrt{(L/2)^2 + D^2}}.
Now, we see that \lambda L is the total charge on the rod. Let us denote this by q.
E_x \amp = k\, \dfrac{q}{D\sqrt{(L/2)^2 + D^2}}.
Therefore, the magnitude is
E = k\, \dfrac{|q|}{D\sqrt{(L/2)^2 + D^2}} = k\, \dfrac{2|q|}{D\sqrt{L^2 + 4\:D^2}},
the direction towards +x if q positive and -x if q negative.

Notice that if P is very far away, our rod would look like a point charge, therefore, our answer should become same as that of point charge. We can see this expectation emerge when we apply D\gt\gt L limit our result in Eq. by just dropping (L/2)^2 compared to D^2.
E_x \amp = k\, \dfrac{q}{D^2}\text{, if } D\gt\gt L.

subsubsection.title: Electric Field of a Charged Ring

sidebyside.p:
The electric field of a uniformly charged ring of radius R with line charge density \lambda (SI units: \text{C/m}) is also easy to find as I will show in derivation in . The electric field a point P that is at a distance D above the middle of the ring has magnitude
E = k \dfrac{|q|D }{ \left( R^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} },
where q=2\pi R L, the total charge on ring.

subsubsection.p:
The direction is away from the ring if \lambda is positive and towards the ring if \lambda is negative. The direction and the magnitude can all be put together in one formula if we use vector notation. With \hat u_z for unit vector in the positive z axis, we will remove the absolute sign around q to write the net field to be
\vec E = k \frac{qD}{\left( R^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}}\, \hat u_z.
Note that this formula does not look anything like the electric field of a point charge either.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Derivation of Electric Field of a Charged Ring

sidebyside.p: Suppose we have a uniformly charged ring of radius R with line charge density \lambda. Derive the formula for the electric field at a point P that is at a distance D above the center of the ring.

hint.p: Only E_z is nonzero due to symmetry.

p.m: \vector E = k \dfrac{ 2\pi R \lambda \, D}{ \left( R^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} }\ \hat u_z.

solution.p: When we deal with a continuous charges, it is helpful to start with pieces of the body, and use point charge formula. Whenever possible, it usually simplifies calculation if you make use of the symmetry. In the present question, since the field point is in the plane that divides the rod in half, there is a symmetry between the upper half and lower half.

To exploit the symmetry in this situation, we notice two things in this problem: (1) every piece of the ring is same distance from the field point P, and (2) the horizontal component of the electric field from two oppositely placed charges on the ring, as shown in , will cancel out, which means that we need to work out only the vertical component.

figure.caption: To find the electric field from charges uniformly spread over the ring, we first look at the two symmetrically placed charges dq_1 and dq_2 of equal amount. We note that their electric field sums to an electric field that is non-zero only along z axis. That tells us that at P, electric field is pointed along z axis. If charge on the rod was positive, the field will be as shown, and if negative the field will be in the opposite direction.

solution.p:
To get an idea of what to proceed, let us look at the z component of the electric field from element of arc length ds, say from dq_1 = \lambda ds . The magnitude of this electric field is
dE_1 = k \dfrac{\lambda\, ds}{ R^2 + D^2 },
where \sqrt{R^2 + D^2} is the direct distance from the dq_1 to the field point P. Now, we need to get its z component by multiplying with \cos\,\theta, where
\cos\theta = \dfrac{D}{ \sqrt{R^2 + D^2} }.
Therefore, the z component will be
dE_{1z} = k \dfrac{\lambda\, ds}{ R^2 + D^2 }\ \dfrac{D}{ \sqrt{R^2 + D^2} }.
Now, we notice that as we go around the ring, everything is same for every element. Therefore, the net field will just be ds replaced by the circumference of the ring. Let us we drop 1 from the subscript since this is the net.
E_{z} = k \dfrac{\lambda\, 2\pi R}{ R^2 + D^2 }\ \dfrac{D}{ \sqrt{R^2 + D^2} }.
We can write this formula more compactly by replacing \lambda\, 2\pi R by the total charge q on the ring, and combining the denominator.
E_{z} = k \dfrac{q\, D}{ \left( R^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} }.
Since this is the only non-zero component, this gives the magnitude of the net field at P.
E = k \dfrac{ |q|\, D}{ \left( R^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} },
and direction towards +z axis if \lambda is positive and -z axis if \lambda is negative. Of course, you can write this in a vector notation as well by using unit vector \hat u_z that points in the positive z direction.
\vec E = k \dfrac{ q\, D}{ \left( R^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} }\ \hat u_z.

exercise.title: Electric Field of Two Charged Rings in a Plane

sidebyside.p: shows two rings of radii R_1 and R_2 with charge densities \lambda_1 and \lambda_2 respectively. (a) Find electric field at point P a distance D above the common center of the rings. (b) What is the field when the rings have equal but opposite total charges?

hint.p: Use the result of one ring and superposition.

answer.p: (a) \hat u_z\ k D \left[ \frac{q_1}{\left( R_1^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}} + \frac{q_2}{\left( R_2^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}} \right], (b) \hat u_z\ k D q_1 \left[ \frac{1}{\left( R_1^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}} + \frac{1}{\left( R_2^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}} \right].

solution.p:
(a) The net electric field will be superposition of the two fields, one by each ring. To be safe with signs, we work with the vector notation. In vector notation, the field by one ring will have the form
\vec E = k \frac{qD}{\left( R^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}}\, \hat u_z.
There will be one term from each ring. The net will be
\vec E_\text{net} \amp = k \frac{q_1D}{\left( R_1^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}}\, \hat u_z + k \frac{q_2D}{\left( R_2^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}}\, \hat u_z. \amp = \hat u_z\ k D \left[ \frac{q_1}{\left( R_1^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}} + \frac{q_2}{\left( R_2^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}} \right].
Here q_1 = 2\pi R_1 \lambda_1 and q_2 = 2\pi R_2 \lambda_2

(b) when q_1 = -q_2, we will have
\vec E_\text{net} = \hat u_z\ k D q_1 \left[ \frac{1}{\left( R_1^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}} + \frac{1}{\left( R_2^2 + D^2\right)^{3/2}} \right].

exercise.title: Electric Fields of Two Rings of Charges on Two Parallel Planes

sidebyside.p: shows two rings of saame radius R with opposite charge densities \pm\lambda placed above each other separated by a distance D. (a) Find the formula for the electric field at an arbitray point P between the rings at a distance a from the center of one of the rings as shown. (b) What is the field at the mid-point between them?

hint.p: Use the formula for electric field from one ring. Beware that the formula derived in this section is for a ring whose center is at the origin of the coordinate system.

answer.p: (a) \hat u_z\ k q \left[ \dfrac{ a}{ \left( R^2 + a^2 \right)^{3/2} } + \dfrac{ (D-a)}{ \left( R^2 + (D-a)^2 \right)^{3/2} } \right], (b) \hat u_z \dfrac{ k q D}{ \left( R^2 + (D/2)^2 \right)^{3/2} }.

solution.title: (a)

sidebyside.p:
(a) I will use the formula derived for one ring. When origin is at the center of the ring, the axis is z axis, and point P is z=a, then the electric field would be
\vec E = k \dfrac{ q\, a}{ \left( R^2 + a^2 \right)^{3/2} }\ \hat u_z,

solution.p:
where q=2\pi R \lambda, the total charge on the ring. The ring at the bottom is like this. So, let us rename this as \vec E_1.
\vec E_1 = k \dfrac{ q\, a}{ \left( R^2 + a^2 \right)^{3/2} }\ \hat u_z,

sidebyside.p: Now, we have the second ring whose center is not at the origin, but it is at z=D. Therefore, distance to the field point P from this ring will not be a but D-a since P is between the two rings.

solution.p:
Furthermore, since this ring is negatively charged, field at this P by this ring will be pointed up in the positive z direction.
\vec E_2 = +k \dfrac{ q\, (D-a)}{ \left( R^2 + (D-a)^2 \right)^{3/2} }\ \hat u_z,
where q is same as above and D \gt a. The net field at P will be a vector sum of these two fields.
\vec E \amp = \vec E_1+ \vec E_2 \amp = \hat u_z\ k q \left[ \dfrac{ a}{ \left( R^2 + a^2 \right)^{3/2} } + \dfrac{ (D-a)}{ \left( R^2 + (D-a)^2 \right)^{3/2} } \right].

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) We just set a=D/2 in the formula we obtained in (a).
\vec E \amp = \hat u_z \dfrac{ k q D}{ \left( R^2 + (D/2)^2 \right)^{3/2} }.

exercise.title: Electric Field of Uniformly Charged Arc

statement.p: A thin wire of length L made of a nonconducting material is bent into a cricular arc of radius R. The wire is then painted with charged paint so that it has a uniform charge of density \lambda (units: C/m). Find the electric field at the center of the arc.

hint.p: Place arc in the xy plane so that it is symmetrical about x axis. Then, compute x component of electric field of an element of the arc.

answer.p:
Magnitude:
E = \left| \frac{2k\lambda}{R}\sin (L/2R) \right|,
and direction away from the arc if \lambda positive and towards arc if negative.

sidebyside.p: Let us place the arc symmetrically about x axis in the xy plane as shown in . This will have the effect of having y component of electric field zero by symmetry and we will need to work out only the x component.

solution.p:
As we did for line and ring, we look at electric field of a small segment and treat it as a point charge. Taking into account the direction of the field as shown in the figure, x component of the electric field from an element of size Rd\theta at angle \theta will be
dE_x = -dE\:\cos\theta = -k\;\frac{\lambda R d\theta }{ R^2}\: \cos\theta.
Since the arc spans from an angle -\theta_0 to \theta_0 with \theta_0 = L/2R using s=R\theta formula, we integrate this to get the net electric field at origin.
E_x \amp = - \frac{k\lambda}{R}\int_{-\theta_0}^{\theta_0}\:\cos\theta\:d\theta \amp = - \frac{2k\lambda}{R}\sin\theta_0 = - \frac{2k\lambda}{R}\sin (L/2R).
Since this is the only non-zero component, magnitude of electric field is just the magnitude of this quantity.
E = \left| \frac{2k\lambda}{R}\sin (L/2R) \right|,
and direction away from the arc if \lambda positive and towards arc if negative.

subsubsection.title: Electric Field of a Charged Disk

sidebyside.p:
The electric field of a uniformly charged disk of radius R with surface charge density \sigma (SI units: \text{C/m}^2) can also be easily worked out. The electric field st a point P that is at a distance D above the middle of the ring has magnitude
E = 2\pi k |\sigma| \left( 1 - \dfrac{D}{\sqrt{R^2 + D^2 }} \right)

subsubsection.p: The direction is away from the disk if \sigma is positive and towards the disk if sigma is negative. Note that this formula does not look anything like the electric field of a point charge either.

An intersting results occurs when we look at a point very close to the disk, i.e., when D \lt\lt R.
E = 2\pi k |\sigma|,\text{ or, } \dfrac{|\sigma|}{2\epsilon_0}.

exercise.title: (Calculus) Electric Field of a Circular Disk Of Uniform Charge Density

sidebyside.p: Suppose we have a disk of radius R with surface charge density \sigma on only one side of the disk. (a) What will be the electric field at a point P that is at a distance D above the center of the disk?

statement.p: (b) Take the limit D\gt\gt R to show that you get the electric field of a point charge.
(c) Take the limit D\lt\lt R and find the expression of the electric field at a point just above the center of the disk.

hint.p: Build disk out of rings. Set up a ring of thickness dr between radius r and r+dr.

answer.p:
(a) E_z= \dfrac{2 k q}{R^2} \left( 1 - \dfrac{D}{\sqrt{R^2 + D^2 }} \right),
(b) E_z = k \dfrac{q}{D^2} ,
(c) E_z= \dfrac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0} .

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) We imagine dividing up the disk into concentric rings as shown in . Consider one representative ring of radius r of thickness dr. The infintesimal charge dq on the ring will be
dq = \sigma\, (2 \pi r dr).

figure.caption: To find the electric field from charges uniformly spread over a disk, we think of the disk as made of infintely many rings. One such representative ring of thickness dr and radius r is shown. The net field from this ring has only the z component non-zero. By adding over all such rings will give the electric field of the whole disk.

solution.p:
The electric field of this ring will have only the z component nonzero. We can utilize the result of electric field of a ring of charges worked out in . We will get the infinitesimal electric field dE_z by the ring here as
dE_z = k\dfrac{ (2 \pi \sigma r dr) \,D}{ \left( r^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} }.
Now, to obtain the contribution of all such rings on the disk, we will integrate (i.e., sum over) from r=0 to r=R, giving us the z component of the net electricv field at P.
E_z \amp = 2 \pi k \sigma D \int_0^R \dfrac{r\, dr}{ \left( r^2 + D^2 \right)^{3/2} } \amp = \pi k \sigma D \int_0^{R^2} \dfrac{dy}{ \left( y + D^2 \right)^{3/2} } \amp = 2\pi k \sigma \left( 1 - \dfrac{D}{\sqrt{R^2 + D^2 }} \right)
We can write this expression in terms of the total charge on the disk
q = \pi R^2 \sigma.
This gives
E_z = \dfrac{2 k q}{R^2} \left( 1 - \dfrac{D}{\sqrt{R^2 + D^2 }} \right).

solution.title: (b)
solution.p:
(b) To take the limit, let us introduce the variable
\epsilon = \dfrac{R^2}{D^2}.
This would mean we are interested in the limit \epsilon \rightarrow 0. Let us express the answer in (a) in \epsilon and R in place of D and R.
E_z = \dfrac{2 k q}{R^2} \left( 1 - \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{ 1 + \epsilon }} \right).
Recall from Calculus the Mclaurin series of \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{ 1 + \epsilon }} as
\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{ 1 + \epsilon }} = 1 - \dfrac{1}{2}\epsilon + \cdots,
Keeping only the leading two terms from this series we get
E_z \amp = \dfrac{2 k q}{R^2} \times \dfrac{1}{2}\epsilon, \amp = \dfrac{ k q}{R^2} \times \dfrac{R^2}{D^2}, \amp = k \dfrac{q}{D^2},
which is the electric field at a distance D from a point charge q.

solution.title: (c)
solution.p:
(c) Let us introduce another symbol for the small parameter.
\delta = \dfrac{D}{R},
We will take \delta\rightarrow 0 limit. Writing in \delta and R
E_z = \dfrac{2 k q}{R^2} \left( 1 - \dfrac{\delta}{\sqrt{1 + \delta^2 }} \right).
The expansion now gives
\left( 1 - \dfrac{\delta}{\sqrt{1 + \delta^2 }} \right) \approx 1.
Therefore, we get
E_z = \dfrac{2 k q}{R^2},
which we can write back in \sigma, the charge density as
E_z = 2\pi k \sigma.
In terms of \epsilon_0, the permittivity of vacuum, with k = 1/4\pi\epsilon_0, we get
E_z = \dfrac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}.
This says that when you get very close to a charged surface, the electric field becomes a constant, independent of the distance to the surface. This turns out to be an important result with many applications.

subsubsection.title: Electric Field Near a Large Uniformly Charged Sheet
subsubsection.p: Suppose you spray one side of a very large plastic sheet uniformly with charge density \sigma (SI unit: \text{C/m}^2) (). The electric field of this system is very useful in study of capacitors as we will see in a later chapter.

We will find electric field at a space point close to the sheet. By close to the sheet, we mean that if the dimensions of sheet are L\times L and the distance to the space point is D, then D \lt \lt L .

If the sheet is large, then the physical situation of the feild point P is same as teh case of a point near the center of a uniformly charged disk. The magnitude in that case was given in Eq. . Therefore, the magnitude of electric field of an infintely large sheet is
E_P = \dfrac{\sigma}{2\epsilon_0}.
The direction of electric field will be away from the sheet both above and below the sheet for a positively charged sheet, i.e., when \sigma \gt 0, and the direction will be towards the sheet. The direction is also perpendicular to the sheet itself as shown in .

figure.caption: The electric field from an infintely large charged sheet with charge density \sigma (SI unit: \text{C/m}^2) is independent of the location of point P. It has magnitude \sigma/2\epsilon_0, where \epsilon_0 is the permittivity of vacuum. The direction is perpendicular to sheet, away from the sheet above and below the sheet if \sigma is positive. The electric field arrows shown in the figure will be reversed for negative charges.

subsubsection.title: Electric Field of Two Oppositely Charged Sheets Facing Each Other
subsubsection.p: Suppose you spray one side of a very large plastic sheet uniformly with a positive charge density +\sigma (SI unit: \text{C/m}^2) and another sheet with negative charge density -\sigma. Then, we place them parallel to each other (). This arrangement is called a parallel plate capacitor and is very important on sotrage of electrical energy as we will see in a later chapter.

sidebyside.p:
We can easily work out electric field here by superposing the electric fields of the each sheet already given in .
As shows, the electic fields of the two plates are in the same direction in the space between the plates but they are in opposite to each other in the outside region.

figure.caption: The electric field of two oppositely charged sheets facing each other.

exercise.title: Electric Charge in Clouds from Electric Field Readings

statement.p: Clouds sometimes build up a net negative charge directly above ground and ground in teh vicinity is net positively charged. Suppose we model this arrangement as a parallel plate capacitor of dimension 1\text{ km} by 1\text{ km} separated by 100\text{ m}. What will be the total charge on the cloud facing the Earth if electric field is measured to be 400\text{ N/C}? Note that uppper part of cloud in this situation is net positive so that cloud as a whole is nearly neutral.

solution.p:
From the electric field between plates of a parallel plate capacitor we have
E = \sigma/\epsilon_0,
where \sigma = Q/A. Therefore, we have
Q \amp = \epsilon_0 E A \amp = 8.854\times 10^{-12} \times 400 \times 10^6 = 3.54 \times 10^{-3}\text{ C}.
